awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Automated Emotional Distress Severity Classification for Children and Adolescents Using Speech Emotion Recognition and AI
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will leverage the emerging science of Speech Emotion Recognition and artificial intelligence (AI) to transform the delivery of personalized behavioral healthcare services for children and adolescents from low-income communities. A strong need exists for a platform to measure mental disorders objectively and enable collaboration between multiple stakeholders for affordable quality mental healthcare. This project advances a talk therapy software that extracts voice biomarkers from 60-second speech samples to measure the severity of emotional distress for children and adolescents. The platform’s voice-based algorithm augments therapists' clinical capabilities – increasing the capacity of community mental health providers to address both quality and the issue of access. 
 
The proposed project develops a voice-based biomarker algorithm trained to understand behavioral and emotional tendencies and anticipate future behaviors to determine if a child’s vocal utterances deviate from age-appropriate linguistic and speech patterns. The company is developing a proprietary clinical voice sample database and repository representing marginalized communities (African American, Latino, and Caucasian within rural communities) that will exceed in both volume and accuracy those of its industry peers. Today, the company’s database consists of a diverse, foundational set and size of voice samples essential for developing a more accurate algorithm(s) to detect and predict emotional disorder severity. The proposed research within Phase II builds on the progress achieved in Phase I, using speech emotion recognition and Machine Learning (ML) to identify measurable biomarkers for trauma and stress. The methodology links trauma, stress, and voice types.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
SBIR Final Report: The Benefit of TQI’s AI-Enabled Mental Health Platform on Improving Treatment Outcomes for Youth from Low-income Communities

Project Summary and Intellectual Merit

Our SBIR Phase II project aimed to develop an AI-enabled mental health platform to transform pediatric mental healthcare, especially for youth from low-income communities. TQIntelligence’s (TQI) platform provides an objective, scalable, and cost-effective solution by assessing psychiatric severity through voice samples. This approach addresses the limitations of traditional mental health assessments, which are often subjective and inaccessible in underserved areas. By leveraging AI and computational linguistics, we have created a tool capable of accurate, real-time assessments validated through extensive data collection and research.

Key milestones demonstrate our progress and underscore the intellectual merit of our approach:

  1. App & Website Launch (October 2024): In October 2024, TQI launched a new app and website, setting the stage for broad market engagement. This release marked a significant step in scaling our impact and amplifying marketing and sales efforts. By November 2024, the app will be available for broad user engagement, laying the groundwork for a full launch in January 2025. This launch enhances our capacity to reach diverse populations and mental health resources for children and adolescents.
  2. Age-Specific Innovation (5-18 years): Our platform is designed to address the mental health needs of children and adolescents aged 5-18. This age-specific approach enables precise screenings and recommendations that align with developmental stages, allowing providers and caregivers to make informed decisions about youth mental health interventions.
  3. Accessible, Integrated Platform: The TQI app’s user-friendly interface and Open API facilitate seamless integration with healthcare providers and digital platforms. This interoperability enables clinicians, schools, and families to access TQI’s mental health resources without additional infrastructure, enhancing accessibility and expanding the reach of our services.
  4. Extensive Clinical Data for Enhanced Precision: TQI’s voice AI platform is powered by thousands of clinical voice samples from behavioral health agencies and schools. This dataset enables highly accurate assessments, significantly enhancing the precision of our algorithm. The breadth of clinical samples ensures that our assessments are culturally and demographically inclusive, reflecting the complexities of youth mental health across diverse communities.
  5. Financial Support and Future Funding: TQI has secured $550,000 in private funding from Jumpstart Foundry, Startup Health, Google for Black Founders, and BCBS Massachusetts. We plan to raise a $1.5 million seed round in 2025 to enhance our platform's capabilities.
  6. Proven Algorithm Accuracy: TQI’s voice AI algorithm consistently achieves over 80% accuracy, supported by three peer-reviewed publications. Our first and second algorithm studies (First and Second Voice Algorithm Published Papers) highlight our scientific rigor and commitment to clinical validation, establishing TQI’s platform as a credible and reliable tool in digital mental health. This level of accuracy reinforces the platform’s capacity to offer precise, objective assessments that support meaningful mental health interventions.
  7. Near-Term R&D in Generative AI: Our near-term research focuses on enhancing TQI’s platform with Vision Transformers and Voice-to-Image innovations, which convert voice data into visual representations. This enables the platform to apply image-recognition algorithms to analyze tone, rhythm, and pitch, identifying patterns linked to emotional distress or trauma. Additionally, Large Language Models (LLMs) enhance our platform's ability to interpret complex language nuances, supporting more responsive, effective treatment planning.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of our project are evident in the enhanced accessibility, affordability, and scalability of mental health resources for vulnerable populations. TQI’s platform specifically targets a pediatric population from low-income communities, addressing the critical need for accessible, data-driven solutions that can support underserved youth.

  1. Expanding Access to Mental Health Services: By making our platform available on Android and iOS devices, we reduce barriers to mental healthcare, especially for low-income families. The Open API enables integration with existing healthcare systems, extending the platform’s reach and allowing providers, schools, and parents to access assessments easily.
  2. Reducing Cost and Improving Efficiency: Our platform provides an affordable alternative to traditional assessments, reducing the burden of in-person evaluations. This cost-effectiveness allows clinics and community organizations to serve more patients without compromising quality. Our research (3rd Paper) demonstrates how this measurement-based system positively impacts treatment outcomes, showing that accessible, cost-effective care can yield substantial benefits.

 

Concluding Remarks

With a new app and website in place, backed by extensive data, strategic partnerships, and a pending plan for funding, TQI is well-positioned to make a significant impact as we prepare for a full launch in January 2025. Our platform’s expanding traction and demonstrated effectiveness reflect a clear path forward in delivering accessible, data-driven mental health solutions to underserved youth and communities.

The outcomes of this project affirm the NSF’s support for high-impact, transformative technologies. TQI’s platform bridges critical gaps in accessibility, accuracy, and affordability in pediatric mental healthcare. By supporting early intervention and leveraging real-time assessments, our platform offers lasting benefits for low-income youth.

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2024
Modified by: Yared N Alemu

Project Summary and Intellectual Merit


Our SBIR Phase II project aimed to develop an AI-enabled mental health platform to transform pediatric mental healthcare, especially for youth from low-income communities. TQIntelligences (TQI) platform provides an objective, scalable, and cost-effective solution by assessing psychiatric severity through voice samples. This approach addresses the limitations of traditional mental health assessments, which are often subjective and inaccessible in underserved areas. By leveraging AI and computational linguistics, we have created a tool capable of accurate, real-time assessments validated through extensive data collection and research.

Extensive Clinical Data for Enhanced Precision: TQIs voice AI platform is powered by thousands of clinical voice samples from behavioral health agencies and schools. This dataset enables highly accurate assessments, significantly enhancing the precision of our algorithm. The breadth of clinical samples ensures that our assessments are culturally and demographically inclusive, reflecting the complexities of youth mental health across diverse communities.
Financial Support and Future Funding: TQI has secured $550,000 in private funding from Jumpstart Foundry, Startup Health, Google for Black Founders, and BCBS Massachusetts. We plan to raise a $1.5 million seed round in 2025 to enhance our platform's capabilities.
Proven Algorithm Accuracy: TQIs voice AI algorithm consistently achieves over 80% accuracy, supported by three peer-reviewed publications. Near-Term R&D in Generative AI: Our near-term research focuses on enhancing TQIs platform with Vision Transformers and Voice-to-Image innovations, which convert voice data into visual representations. The broader impacts of our project are evident in the enhanced accessibility, affordability, and scalability of mental health resources for vulnerable populations. TQIs platform specifically targets a pediatric population from low-income communities, addressing the critical need for accessible, data-driven solutions that can support underserved youth.

Expanding Access to Mental Health Services: By making our platform available on Android and iOS devices, we reduce barriers to mental healthcare, especially for low-income families. The Open API enables integration with existing healthcare systems, extending the platforms reach and allowing providers, schools, and parents to access assessments easily.
Reducing Cost and Improving Efficiency: Our platform provides an affordable alternative to traditional assessments, reducing the burden of in-person evaluations. This cost-effectiveness allows clinics and community organizations to serve more patients without compromising quality. Concluding Remarks


With a new app and website in place, backed by extensive data, strategic partnerships, and a pending plan for funding, TQI is well-positioned to make a significant impact as we prepare for a full launch in January 2025. Our platforms expanding traction and demonstrated effectiveness reflect a clear path forward in delivering accessible, data-driven mental health solutions to underserved youth and communities.


The outcomes of this project affirm the NSFs support for high-impact, transformative technologies. TQIs platform bridges critical gaps in accessibility, accuracy, and affordability in pediatric mental healthcare. By supporting early intervention and leveraging real-time assessments, our platform offers lasting benefits for low-income youth.
